title: 114_s247
content: The "Expatriate Terrorist Act" is the short title of the Act. It addresses the loss of nationality due to support of terrorism. Section 349(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to specify acts that can result in loss of U.S. nationality, such as obtaining naturalization in a foreign state, pledging allegiance to a foreign entity, or serving in the armed forces of a foreign state. The Immigration and Nationality Act specifies acts that can lead to loss of U.S. nationality, including serving in the armed forces of a foreign state engaged in hostilities against the United States or becoming a member of a designated foreign terrorist organization. The Immigration and Nationality Act outlines actions that can result in loss of U.S. nationality, such as serving in a foreign state's armed forces against the U.S. or joining a designated foreign terrorist organization. This can include making a formal renunciation of U.S. nationality before a diplomatic or consular officer abroad, or in the U.S. during wartime with approval from the Attorney General. The Immigration and Nationality Act specifies actions that can lead to loss of U.S. nationality, including committing acts of treason or conspiring against the United States. This can result in renunciation of U.S. nationality before a diplomatic or consular officer abroad, or with approval from the Attorney General during wartime. The Passport Act of 1926 is amended to allow for the revocation or denial of passports and passport cards to individuals who are members of foreign terrorist organizations. The Passport Act of 1926 is amended to prohibit the issuance of passports to individuals who are members of designated foreign terrorist organizations. Passports can be revoked if an individual is found to be associated with such organizations. Individuals have the right to request a due process hearing within 60 days of receiving notice of passport denial or revocation. Individuals have the right to request a due process hearing within 60 days of receiving notice of passport denial or revocation.
